questions.text: A 17-year-old boy comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of pain in his left wrist. The pain was relieved with ibuprofen. That morning the pain increased and he started to have chills and malaise. Last week he had self-resolving left knee pain. He is otherwise healthy and has not had any trauma to the wrist. He recently returned from a camping trip with his church group to Minnesota. He is sexually active with one female partner, who uses a diaphragm for contraception. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F). Examination shows several painless violaceous vesiculopustular lesions on the dorsum of both wrists and hands; two lesions are present on the left palm. There is swelling and erythema of the left wrist with severe tenderness to palpation and passive movement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lyme arthritis is a clinical feature of late Lyme disease (stage III) and can manifest with intermittent arthritis. While the patient's recent camping trip to Minnesota puts him at an increased risk of contracting tick-borne diseases, late Lyme disease develops months to years after a tick bite. Moreover, a violaceous vesiculopustular rash is not typically seen in Lyme disease.
Image Description:

Left torso of a patient

A round, erythematous skin lesion with discrete central scaling and typical target-shape appearance is seen.

These findings are highly suggestive of erythema chronicum migrans in Lyme disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with acute rheumatic fever (ARF) usually present with migratory polyarthritis and cutaneous lesions, as does this patient. However, in contrast to the painless violaceous vesiculopustular lesions described in the vignette, ARF manifests with subcutaneous nodules and erythema marginatum (annular erythema on the trunk and extremities). Additionally, ARF is usually associated with other symptoms such as pancarditis or Sydenham chorea.
Image Description:

Left upper arm of a child diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever (ARF)

Erythematous plaques with areas of central clearing are visible on the ventral aspect of the forearm.

This is characteristic of erythema marginatum, the characteristic annular erythema occuring in 10% of attacks of acute rheumatic fever in children, caused by group A streptococcus.

C) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can manifest with arthritis and skin involvement. However, SLE is characterized by symmetric polyarthritis, rather than monoarthritis, and a maculopapular rash that develops on sun-exposed areas of the skin, rather than the palms or soles. In addition, most patients with SLE develop facial erythema that spares the nasolabial folds (malar rash), which is not seen here.
Image Description:

An erythematous macular rash is visible over the nasal bridge, right cheek (malar eminence), and the right brow. The rash has spared the nasolabial fold.

This is the characteristic appearance of the malar rash typically seen in systemic lupus erythematosus. This rash is also referred to as a “butterfly rash” because it typically affects both malar eminences symmetrically and resembles the wings of a butterfly.

D) CORRECT:

Gonorrhea is the second most frequently reported infectious disease in the US and can manifest in a localized form (e.g., as urethritis, pelvic inflammatory disease) or as disseminated gonococcal infection (e.g., arthritis-dermatitis syndrome, purulent gonococcal arthritis). Gonorrhea is most commonly transmitted during unprotected sex. Arthritis-dermatitis syndrome typically manifests with migratory, asymmetric arthritis, tenosynovitis, and vesicular, pustular, or maculopapular lesions on the trunk and extremities, sometimes involving the palms and soles.

The diagnostic workup of suspected gonococcal arthritis includes blood cultures, synovial fluid analysis, and nucleic acid amplification testing.

E) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis typically presents with a triad of urethritis, conjunctivitis, and migratory polyarthritis most commonly in young men. While this patient presents with migratory polyarthritis, other associated symptoms of reactive arthritis are absent. He also has no history of recent gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections, making this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: There are many conditions that can cause both dermatitis and arthritis, but the accompanying fever, rapid onset of symptoms, and lack of prior illness or other symptoms may help distinguish between them.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of fever and severe left knee pain for the past week. She has not sustained any trauma or injury to the area, nor has she traveled or taken part in outdoor activities in the recent past. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals; her last menstrual period was 1 week ago. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 106/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple painless pustular lesions on her ankles and the dorsum and soles of her feet bilaterally, as well as a swollen, erythematous, exquisitely tender left knee. Her wrists are also mildly edematous and tender, with pain on extension. An x-ray of the knees shows tissue swelling. Arthrocentesis of the knee shows yellow purulent fluid. Gram stain is negative. Analysis of the synovial fluid shows a leukocyte count of 58,000/mm3 with 93% neutrophils and no crystals. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Empiric therapy with IV vancomycin and ceftazidime is the treatment of choice in patients with septic arthritis if Gram stain is negative and there are no risk factors for STDs. Vancomycin is effective against gram-positive bacteria such as Staphylococcus aureus (including MRSA), and ceftazidime is effective against gram-negative rods such as Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas. This patient's presentation is consistent with DGI, which requires different management.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral penicillin V is used to treat streptoccocal infections or for prophylaxis in diseases like rheumatic fever (RF). Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory condition that affects the heart, joints, skin, and brain and commonly develops after a streptococcal throat infection. Even though this woman fulfills one of the major criteria for RF (polyarthritis), she has no history of preceding streptoccocal infection, nor are the other criteria fulfilled (e.g., signs of carditis, erythema marginatum, Sydenham chorea, or subcutaneous nodules), making RF unlikely. RF would also not explain this patient's pustular dermatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydroxychloroquine is an antimalarial drug that is also used in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) because of its anti-inflammatory effect. However, this patient lacks typical features of SLE (e.g., malar rash, weight loss, pain in the small joints) or RA (joint pain and stiffness in the hands and fingers). More importantly, the arthrocentesis results here indicate septic arthritis, whereas both RA and SLE would involve aseptic joint inflammation (leukocyte count typically < 50,000 mm3).

D) CORRECT:

Intravenous or intramuscular ceftriaxone is the preferred initial treatment for DGI. Although this patient only has signs of gonococcal infection, coinfection with chlamydia is common (and has not been excluded here), and oral doxycycline is used to treat it. In addition to treating the patient, testing and treatment should be offered to her sexual contacts. Although Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a bacteria that can be seen on Gram stain and routine culture of synovial fluid, these tests are positive in less than 50% of samples and are therefore unreliable. Instead, nucleic acid amplification is conducted to confirm the diagnosis.
Image Description:

Infectious pustule with accompanying erythema on the palmar side of index finger.

E) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is an antibiotic that may be used to treat Lyme disease. The disseminated form of Lyme disease can also manifest with polyarthritis. However, this patient has no history of exposure to the outdoors and patients with Lyme disease normally have erythema migrans during the first stage (before signs of dissemination), not a pustular rash. Furthermore, joint fluid analysis in Lyme disease would show aseptic inflammation (leukocyte count typically < 50,000 mm3).

F) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice for DGI. However, since chlamydial coinfection has not been excluded, ceftriaxone monotherapy would not be recommended.

G) INCORRECT:

Intravenous vancomycin is used to treat septic arthritis caused by gram-positive cocci. The presence of gram-positive cocci on staining indicates a staphylococcal or streptococcal infection. Typically, these infections occur in older patients, are acute, and involve one joint at a time. They are not associated with pustular rashes. The incidence of nongonococcal arthritis in individuals practicing unsafe sex (such as this patient) is lower than that of gonococcal arthritis.
questions.hint: Pustular dermatitis that involves the soles of the feet, septic arthritis, and a history of inconsistent condom use suggest disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 14 weeks' gestation, comes to the physician with a 3-day history of abnormal vaginal discharge. She has not had fever, chills, or abdominal pain. Her initial prenatal examination at 10 weeks' gestation showed no abnormalities. The patient has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. She is sexually active with one male partner and they do not use condoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows an inflamed and friable cervix. There is a mucopurulent, malodorous discharge from the cervical os. There is no uterine or cervical motion tenderness. Vaginal pH measurement shows a pH of 4.3. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wet mount preparation of vaginal smear can be used to detect flagellated protozoa characteristic of trichomoniasis and clue cells characteristic of bacterial vaginosis (BV). These conditions can cause malodorous vaginal discharge but typically result in an elevated vaginal pH (pH > 4.5). In addition, isolated cervicitis is not a typical manifestation of either of these conditions. A wet mount preparation is unreliable in diagnosing the most common infectious causes of cervicitis because these infections only cause the nonspecific finding of a high leukocyte number on the wet mount.

B) INCORRECT:

The amine test (whiff test) is used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis (BV), which can cause malodorous vaginal discharge. However, BV typically manifests with an elevated vaginal pH (pH > 4.5) and a gray or milky rather than mucopurulent discharge. Isolated cervicitis makes BV highly unlikely. The amine test does not evaluate for the most common infectious causes of cervicitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Urine analysis and culture would be the most appropriate initial step if a urinary tract infection (UTI) was suspected. This patient presents with cervicitis and does not report features of a UTI (e.g., dysuria, urgency, frequency, suprapubic pain).

D) CORRECT:

A nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) is the preferred modality for diagnosing Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae infections, which are the most common causes of cervicitis. NAAT can also diagnose certain uncommon causes of acute cervicitis such as trichomoniasis. Patients with confirmed gonorrhea, chlamydia, or trichomoniasis should also be screened for HIV and syphilis. Chlamydia and gonorrhea testing is indicated during the initial prenatal visit (at approx. 10 weeks' gestation) in all patients < 25 years of age and in patients ≥ 25 years of age with risk factors for sexually transmitted infections.

See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.

E) INCORRECT:

A potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation is used to diagnose vulvovaginal candidiasis, which can manifest with vaginal discharge and a normal vaginal pH of 4.0–4.5. The discharge, however, is usually odorless and white, crumbly, and sticky rather than mucopurulent. In addition, features of inflammatory vaginitis (e.g., intense pruritus, vaginal burning, dyspareunia, vulvar and vaginal erythema) are typically present. Isolated cervicitis is not typical of vulvovaginal candidiasis. A KOH preparation does not evaluate for the most common infectious causes of cervicitis.
questions.hint: An inflamed, friable cervix with a mucopurulent discharge from the cervical os in a sexually active patient suggests cervicitis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal discharge for 4 days. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Twelve months ago, she was diagnosed with trichomoniasis, for which she and her partner were treated with a course of an antimicrobial. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. Her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive that she has been taking for the past 4 years. A Gram stain of her vaginal fluid is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is responsible for gonorrhea, an STI that presents with purulent, creamy vaginal discharge. This patient's history of inconsistent condom use and previous trichomoniasis indicates an elevated risk of future STIs. The presence of gram-negative intracellular diplococci in the microscopy of this patient's discharge specimen confirms that the infection is caused by N. gonorrhoeae.

Because Gram stain is often false negative, the test of choice for detecting gonorrhea is the nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT).

B) INCORRECT:

Gardnerella vaginalis is a gram-variable rod that can commonly cause infections of the genitourinary tract (bacterial vaginosis) associated with a painless vaginal discharge. However, the discharge in bacterial vaginosis has a characteristic fishy odor. Moreover, microscopy would characteristically contain 'Clue cells', which are vaginal epithelial cells covered with bacteria. The absence of these hallmark features makes this an unlikely causal agent.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a vaginal smear specimen (vaginal wet mount; medium power magnification)

Squamous cells with a stippled appearance and fuzzy borders can be seen (clue cells) due to bacteria adhering to the cell surface.

The presence of clue cells is one of the four Amsel criteria (besides thin, white, yellow, homogeneous discharge; vaginal fluid pH of > 4.5; and a fishy odor after adding 10% potassium hydroxide solution to wet mount) for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Gardnerella vaginalis is the most common cause of this condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus ducreyi causes a highly contagious STI called chancroid. Although this organism could appear as a gram-negative coccobacillus on microscopy, it causes both highly painful lesions and lymphadenopathy. The absence of these hallmark features makes this an unlikely causative agent.

D) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella granulomatis is a gram-negative bacillus that causes granuloma inguinale. Although this patient demonstrates an elevated risk of STI contraction (as evidenced by inconsistent condom use, with a history of previous STI), granuloma inguinale would typically present with painless genital lesions. Also, the absence of gram-negative bacilli in the microscopy of this patient's discharge specimen confirms that the infection is not caused by this bacterium.
Image Description:

Perianal region of a female patient with Klebsiella granulomatis infection

Multiple confluent, partially ulcerated papules are visible.

Diagnosis was confirmed via visualization of darkly staining Donovan bodies in biopsy crush preparations.

E) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis is an obligate intracellular bacterium and the most common sexually transmitted genitourinary infection. The majority of patients are asymptomatic or present with purulent vaginal discharge, as seen here. A Gram stain would not show intracellular diplococci; this pathogen can be detected by Giemsa stain, but sensitivity is low; so it is usually identified using PCR (nucleic acid amplification test).

F) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans is a fungus and a common cause of vulvovaginitis. Although C. albicans also causes vaginal discharge, it is typically associated with intense pruritus and a burning sensation in the vagina. Also, microscopic examination of the discharge would show pseudohyphae upon application of potassium hydroxide and would not include gram staining.

G) INCORRECT:

T. pallidum causes syphilis. The characteristic genital lesion of primary syphilis (raised genital papule that evolves into a painless, firm ulcer with indurated borders) is not seen in this patient, nor is associated lymphadenopathy. Also, T. pallidum does not gram stain well and is too small to be seen in conventional light microscopy. Instead, T. pallidum is visualized with dark field microscopy and appears as thin, corkscrew-shaped spirochetes.
questions.hint: The Gram stain shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci – the pathogen responsible for a common sexually transmitted infection (STI).

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of burning with urination and purulent urethral discharge for the past 3 days. He is sexually active with multiple female partners. Several months ago he was diagnosed with urethritis caused by gram-negative diplococci and received antibiotic treatment with complete resolution of his symptoms. A Gram stain of the patient's urethral discharge shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci. Which of the following properties of the infecting organism most contributed to the pathogenesis of this patient's recurrent infection?

choices.text: Production of enzymes that hydrolyze urea

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Expression of beta-lactamase genes is common to many bacteria, especially gram-negative and anaerobic organisms. The enzymes provide resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics. This patient was successfully treated for his initial infection with N. gonorrhoeae (likely with the beta-lactam antibiotic ceftriaxone, the first-line treatment). Therefore, it is unlikely that beta-lactamase expression played a role in reinfection.

B) INCORRECT:

N. gonorrhoeae is a facultative intracellular organism, as it resides and replicates within neutrophilic granulocytes (and epithelial cells) to evade the immune system. Although the intracellular nature of this pathogen contributes to its ability to establish infections, it does not enhance its ability to reinfect the same host after successful antibiotic treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

The synthesis of a polysaccharide capsule is an important virulence factor for Neisseria meningitidis as it enables the pathogen to evade phagocytosis. However, this patient has an infection with N. gonorrhoeae, which does not produce a capsule.

D) INCORRECT:

Although N. gonorrhoeae does, in fact, express immunogenic proteins, these can be masked to evade host immune response. This patient's reinfection is better explained by a different characteristic of the causal organism.

E) INCORRECT:

Production of enzymes that hydrolyze urea is an important virulence factor for urease-producing bacteria such as Proteus mirabilis and H. pylori. Urease catalyzes the conversion of urea to ammonium (and CO2), which raises the surrounding pH and enables survival in an acidic environment. N. gonorrhoeae, however, does not produce urease.

F) CORRECT:

Pili are an important virulence factor that mediate the attachment of N. gonorrhoeae to the epithelial cells of a host. Anti-pilin antibodies that are directed against specific pilus proteins can prevent attachment of the pathogen. To circumvent this host immune response, N. gonorrhoeae utilizes DNA recombination to create a high frequency of antigenic variation of expressed pilus proteins; these proteins thus are no longer recognized by the initial antibodies. This particular virulence factor has made it difficult to create a vaccine that targets the gonococcal pili.
Image Description:

Colorized scanning electron micrograph of a laboratory culture

There are coffee bean-shaped diplococci with pili extending from their surface.
questions.hint: This patient's burning sensation with urination and Gram stain results (gram-negative intracellular diplococci) are consistent with gonococcal urethritis. Neisseria gonorrhoeae has developed several virulence factors that prevent host immune recognition.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of pain in her right knee. Last week she had right wrist pain. She has no history of recent trauma. She returned from summer camp in Connecticut 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Examination shows several painless vesiculopustular lesions on the back and one lesion on the right sole of the foot. There is swelling of the right knee with tenderness to palpation. Passive extension of the right wrist and fingers elicits pain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis typically presents with a triad of urethritis, conjunctivitis, and migratory arthritis most commonly in young adults. While this patient presents with migratory arthritis, other associated symptoms of reactive arthritis are absent. She also has no history of recent gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections, making this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common overall cause of septic arthritis in adults, children > 2 years of age, and in patients, who have recently undergone invasive joint procedures. Staphylococcal septic arthritis typically presents with fever, joint pain, and swelling of the affected joint, most commonly the knee, as seen in this patient. However, in young adults who are sexually active, such as this patient, Staphylococcus aureus is not the most likely cause of septic arthritis, nor does it manifest with migratory arthritis, tenosynovitis, or a painless vesiculopustular rash.

C) INCORRECT:

SLE can present with arthritis and skin lesions, but the lesions are in the form of a rash that is most commonly found in light-exposed areas such as the face (malar rash). It does not typically present with vesiculopustular lesions on the back or the sole. Additionally, the disease usually has a slower onset and presents with associated symptoms such as pleuritis, pericarditis, renal failure, vasculitis, Raynaud phenomenon, or thromboembolism.
Image Description:

An erythematous macular rash is visible over the nasal bridge, right cheek (malar eminence), and the right brow. The rash has spared the nasolabial fold.

This is the characteristic appearance of the malar rash typically seen in systemic lupus erythematosus. This rash is also referred to as a “butterfly rash” because it typically affects both malar eminences symmetrically and resembles the wings of a butterfly.

D) INCORRECT:

Lyme arthritis is a clinical feature of late Lyme disease (stage III) and can manifest with intermittent arthritis. While this patient's recent summer camp in Connecticut puts her at an increased risk of contracting tick-borne diseases, late Lyme disease develops months to years after a tick bite. Moreover, a vesiculopustular rash is not typically seen in Lyme disease.
Image Description:

Left torso of a patient

A round, erythematous skin lesion with discrete central scaling and typical target-shape appearance is seen.

These findings are highly suggestive of erythema chronicum migrans in Lyme disease.

E) CORRECT:

Infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the second most commonly reported infectious disease in the US and can manifest in a localized (e.g., urethritis, pelvic inflammatory disease) or disseminated (arthritis-dermatitis syndrome, purulent gonococcal arthritis) form. The disease is most commonly transmitted during unprotected sexual intercourse. Arthritis-dermatitis syndrome typically manifests with migratory, asymmetric arthritis, tenosynovitis, and vesicular, pustular, or maculopapular lesions on the trunk and extremities (sometimes involving the palms and soles), as seen in this patient.

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a common cause of septic arthritis in sexually active young adults.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with acute rheumatic fever usually present with migratory arthritis and cutaneous lesions, as does this patient. In contrast to the painless vesiculopustular lesions described here, though, cutaneous manifestations include subcutaneous nodules and erythema marginatum (annular erythema on the trunk and extremities). Additionally, the condition is usually associated with other symptoms such as pancarditis or Sydenham chorea and is preceded by a history of streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis.
questions.hint: There are many conditions that can cause both dermatitis and oligoarthritis, but the accompanying fever, painless vesiculopustular lesions, tenosynovitis (pain on passive extension of wrist and fingers), and lack of prior illness or other symptoms may help distinguish between them.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of pain and swelling of her right knee joint and left wrist. She went camping with her new boyfriend 3 weeks ago but does not recall any tick bites. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F). Examination of the right knee shows swelling, warmth, and tenderness on passive movement. There is a tender pustule on the sole of the left foot. Arthrocentesis of the right knee joint yields 8 mL of cloudy fluid with a leukocyte count of 51,000/mm3 (90% segmented neutrophils with intracellular organisms). Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autoantibody production is seen in chronic inflammatory joint diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), both of which predominantly affect women. However, as opposed to this patient's asymmetric oligoarthritis, RA and SLE are associated with symmetric polyarthritis, often involving the proximal interphalangeal finger joints. Morning stiffness would also be expected in RA. Skin manifestations include malar rash in SLE and rheumatoid nodules in RA, but pustular lesions would not be seen. Systemic symptoms are common in both conditions. Synovial fluid analysis in RA will show an increased WBC count but no intracellular organisms.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous drug use is associated with an increased risk of septic arthritis, which manifests with pain, swelling, warmth, and limited range of motion of a single joint, unlike the asymmetric oligoarthritis seen in this patient. Staphylococcus aureus is the most commonly isolated organism, followed by Streptococcus and Pseudomonas spp., neither of which are consistent with the intracellular organisms found in this patient's synovial fluid analysis.

C) CORRECT:

Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which can either manifest in a genitourinary, often asymptomatic form or as disseminated disease with arthritis-dermatitis syndrome or purulent arthritis. Arthritis-dermatitis syndrome typically manifests with migratory, asymmetric arthritis, tenosynovitis, and vesicular, pustular, or maculopapular lesions on the trunk and extremities (sometimes involving the palms and soles), as seen in this patient. Synovial fluid analysis showing an increased neutrophil-dominated leukocyte count with intracellular organisms further supports the diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Infection with Borrelia burgdorferi from an Ixodes tick bite can cause Lyme disease. Lyme arthritis is a feature of late disease (stage III), which can manifest with asymmetric oligoarthritis. While this patient's recent camping trip poses a risk for tick-borne diseases, late Lyme disease develops months to years after a tick bite. Moreover, though B. burgdorferi is an intracellular organism, it is rarely detected in synovial fluid. Finally, a vesiculopustular rash is not typically seen in Lyme disease.

E) INCORRECT:

HLA-B27 positivity is associated with reactive arthritis, which occurs in response to a bacterial infection of the gastrointestinal or genitourinary tract. Reactive arthritis typically presents with a triad of urethritis, conjunctivitis, and migratory arthritis. While this patient has migratory arthritis, other associated symptoms are absent. The lack of a history of a recent infection makes this diagnosis unlikely. Moreover, since reactive arthritis is aseptic, synovial fluid analysis would not show any organism and only a moderately increased leukocyte count.

F) INCORRECT:

Left untreated, bacterial pharyngitis due to group A Streptococcus can lead to acute rheumatic fever (ARF). ARF manifests with arthritis and cutaneous lesions, as seen in this patient. However, arthritis is usually polyarticular, and cutaneous manifestations are not pustular but include subcutaneous nodules and erythema marginatum. Additionally, the condition is usually associated with other symptoms such as pancarditis or Sydenham chorea. Finally, synovial fluid analysis would not show intracellular organisms.
questions.hint: A positive nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) would confirm the diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 13 weeks' gestation, comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of burning pain during urination. She has been sexually active with different male partners during the pregnancy and did not use condoms. She has not had any fever, chills, or pelvic pain. Physical examination shows thick, purulent discharge from the urethra. Urine dipstick shows leukocyte esterase, urinalysis shows 10 WBCs/hpf, and Gram stain of the urethral swab shows polymorphonuclear leukocytes with intracellular gram-negative diplococci. Nucleic acid amplification testing confirms infection with a single pathogen. Pelvic ultrasound shows a viable intrauterine pregnancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral levofloxacin is a second-line treatment option for confirmed infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. Genitourinary Chlamydia infection can manifest with dysuria and urethral discharge in a sexually active patient. However, this patient's urinalysis indicates infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae, for which levofloxacin is not a recommended treatment. Moreover, fluoroquinolones are contraindicated in pregnancy due to possible damage to the fetal cartilage.

B) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular penicillin G is the first-line treatment for infection with Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis. However, it is not recommended for the empiric treatment of urethritis because of gonococcal antibiotic resistance. Primary syphilis typically manifests with nontender inguinal lymphadenopathy and a chancre, a painless, genital ulcer with indurated borders. Thick, purulent urethral discharge is not typically seen.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral cefixime and doxycycline in a single dose is an alternative regimen for empiric treatment of urethritis. However, this combination is not a first-line treatment because the drugs are lower efficacy and face increasing gonococcal antimicrobial resistance. Moreover, doxycycline is contraindicated during pregnancy because it has a harmful impact on fetal skeletal development.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral erythromycin is a second-line treatment option for confirmed infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. Genitourinary Chlamydia infection can manifest with dysuria and urethral discharge in a sexually active patient. However, this patient's urinalysis indicates infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae, for which erythromycin is not a recommended treatment. Moreover, studies have reported cardiovascular and urinary malformations after exposure to erythromycin in pregnancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral azithromycin was formerly used to treat Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. However, this therapy is no longer recommended because of increasing rates of drug resistance. Oral azithromycin is a first-line treatment option for confirmed chlamydial urethritis.

F) CORRECT:

A single dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone is used to treat urethritis due to Neisseria gonorrhoeae. This drug is safe to use during pregnancy. Combination therapy is only recommended if coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis has not yet been excluded. In such cases, ceftriaxone should be combined with azithromycin (in pregnant patients) or doxycycline (in nonpregnant adults). Sexual partners should be treated simultaneously to avoid reinfection.

Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) for C. trachomatis is always warranted to assess for coinfection, and screening for HIV infection should be performed. NAAT for N. gonorrhea should be done 3 months after completion of therapy because of the risk of reinfection.
questions.hint: A thick, purulent urethral discharge that shows polymorphonuclear leukocytes with intracellular gram-negative diplococci on Gram stain indicates a diagnosis of gonorrhea. Risk factors for this condition include unprotected sexual intercourse and multiple sexual partners.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of urinary frequency, pelvic discomfort, and burning with urination for the past 7 days. She has been sexually active with 3 male partners over the past 6 months and usually uses condoms for contraception. One year ago, she was treated for a genital herpes simplex infection. She has a history of chronic ear infections and asthma. Her only medication is a combined fluticasone-albuterol inhaler. She does not smoke cigarettes and drinks alcohol socially up to 4 times per week. Her temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Pelvic examination shows normal-appearing external genitalia. Erythema and sparse discharge are present at the urethral meatus. On bimanual examination, the uterus is mobile, and there is no cervical motion tenderness. A Gram stain of the patient's urethral swab is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vaginal thrush, caused by Candida, is a fungal infection that can manifest with dysuria. However, this patient does not have other typical features of vaginal thrush, including white, cottage cheese-like vaginal discharge, vulvovaginal erythema, pruritus, and dyspareunia. In addition, the diagnosis of vaginal thrush is made with wet mount microscopy with KOH staining that shows budding yeast and pseudohyphae.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast

B) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis urethritis is a common sexually-transmitted infection that manifests with urinary frequency, dysuria, and urethral erythema and discharge. However, C. trachomatis, an obligate intracellular bacterium, is not detectable by Gram stain. C. trachomatis may be visible as cytoplasmic inclusion bodies on Giemsa stain, but sensitivity is low; a nucleic acid amplification test is the preferred diagnostic test.

C) INCORRECT:

Mycoplasma genitalium urethritis is a sexually-transmitted infection that manifests with urinary frequency, dysuria, and urethral erythema and discharge. However, M. genitalium lacks a cell wall and is, therefore, not detectable by Gram stain. M. genitalium is a fastidious bacterial species; a nucleic acid amplification test of a first-void urine sample (for male patients) or vaginal swab (for female patients) is the preferred diagnostic test.

D) CORRECT:

The swab of this patient's urethral discharge shows the presence of Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a gram-negative, intracellular diplococcus, which causes gonorrhea. This patient, who lacks the features of pelvic inflammatory disease (e.g., fever, abdominal pain, cervical motion tenderness), has uncomplicated gonorrhea and should be treated with a single dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone. However, because coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis is common and has not been excluded, she should also receive treatment with oral doxycycline for seven days.

Gram stain for Neisseria gonorrhoeae often results in a false negative result. The test of choice for detecting gonorrhea is nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT), which has both high sensitivity and specificity for this condition. The diagnosis of chlamydia is also made with NAAT.

E) INCORRECT:

Trichomonas vaginalis urethritis is a sexually-transmitted infection that manifests with urinary frequency, dysuria, and urethral erythema and discharge. However, the diagnosis of trichomoniasis is made with wet mount microscopy that shows motile protozoa.
Image Description:

Phase contrast photomicrograph of vaginal discharge (high magnification)

These parasites with flagella (blue overlay) are Trichomonas vaginalis, the causative pathogen of trichomonal vaginitis.

In the center, two squamous epithelial cells can be seen.

F) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli cystitis is a common urinary tract infection that manifests with urinary frequency and dysuria. However, it does not typically cause urethral erythema or discharge. In addition, Gram stain of urine specimens obtained from patients infected with E. coli typically shows gram-negative bacilli rather than gram-negative, intracellular diplococci.

G) INCORRECT:

In female patients, primary syphilis typically manifests with a solitary, raised, vulvovaginal or anal papule that evolves into a painless, firm ulcer with indurated borders (i.e., chancre) with nontender, inguinal lymphadenopathy. In addition, Treponema pallidum, the causative pathogen of syphilis, does not usually appear on Gram stain.
questions.hint: Gram stain of the patient's urethral swab shows gram-negative, intracellular diplococci.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the office because of a 5-day history of a urethral discharge and painful urination. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His only medications are metformin and amlodipine. He is sexually active in a monogamous relationship with his wife and does not use condoms. He reports that his wife does not have similar symptoms. He works as a long-haul truck driver. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg. Genital examination shows purulent discharge from the urethral meatus. There is no scrotal swelling or tenderness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Nucleic acid amplification testing of urethral discharge is positive for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and negative for Chlamydia trachomatis. The results of a screening test for HIV and a rapid plasma reagin test are negative. The physician counsels the patient on the need to return for a follow-up visit and bring his wife into the office for testing. The patient says that it is difficult for them to take time off from work, and they can only come for a visit in several weeks. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intramuscular ceftriaxone for the patient only
Oral cefixime for the patient and his wife
Intramuscular ceftriaxone for the patient and oral cefixime for his wife
Oral doxycycline for the patient and his wife
Intramuscular ceftriaxone for the patient and oral cefixime and doxycycline for his wife

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although intramuscular ceftriaxone can be used to treat gonorrhea, sexual partners, such as this patient's wife, should also receive treatment. EPT is recommended for all sexual partners of the patient from the past 60 days to treat the infection and avoid reinfections.

B) INCORRECT:

Although oral cefixime can be used as an alternative regimen to treat individuals with gonorrhea and their sexual partners, this therapy has limited efficacy and should only be considered if first-line treatment is unavailable.

C) CORRECT:

A single dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone is the first-line treatment for uncomplicated gonorrhea of the cervix, urethra, rectum, and pharynx in patients in whom concurrent chlamydia infection has been excluded. To prevent reinfections, the CDC recommends that all sexual partners from the past 60 days be evaluated and treated with the same regimen as the patient. If sexual partners cannot be evaluated in a timely manner, EPT with a single dose of oral cefixime is recommended. Oral doxycycline should be added to the treatment if chlamydia infection has not been excluded in the index patient. In addition to EPT, sexual partners should be provided with written information on gonorrhea, its treatment, and adverse effects of medication. They should also be advised to seek medical evaluation if symptoms or adverse events occur.

EPT is legally allowed in most states, although under varying conditions. There is no state that prohibits EPT.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline is the first-line treatment for C. trachomatis infection, which can manifest with urethral discharge and dysuria. However, this patient tested positive only for N. gonorrhea, which is not treated with doxycycline.

E) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular ceftriaxone can be used to treat gonorrhea. Dual therapy with both oral cefixime and doxycycline is indicated for sexual partners if coinfection with chlamydia is either suspected or cannot be ruled out in the index patient. However, because the index patient is negative for C. trachomatis, dual therapy is unnecessary.
questions.hint: Expedited partner therapy (EPT) is indicated for certain sexually transmitted infections (STI).

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man with HIV is hospitalized with a 10-day history of severe rectal pain, rectal urgency, and mucopurulent rectal discharge. He has adhered to antiretroviral therapy and has an undetectable HIV viral load with a CD4 count of 475 cells per mm3 (reference range, 400–1600). He has a history of genital herpes and is taking daily suppressive valacyclovir. He reports that during the past year, he has engaged in receptive anal sex with multiple new male partners and did not use condoms.
On examination, he has a temperature of 36.8°C, a blood pressure of 126/70 mm Hg, and a heart rate of 90 beats per minute.
Laboratory testing shows a leukocyte count of 9000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000).
What is the most likely infectious cause of this patient’s proctitis?

choices.text: Herpes simplex virus that is resistant to valacyclovir

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The most common infectious causes of proctitis in people who engage in receptive anal sex without condoms are gonorrhea, herpes simplex virus (HSV), chlamydia, and syphilis. Up to 10% of cases can be caused by multiple infections.

Key learning point: One of the most common causes of infectious proctitis in people who engage in receptive anal sex without condoms is gonorrhea.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient’s lack of systemic symptoms, fever, or colitis argues against enteroinvasive bacterial pathogens, such as Shigella.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient’s lack of systemic symptoms, fever, or colitis argues against enteroinvasive bacterial pathogens, such as Clostridioides difficile.

D) INCORRECT:

HSV is unlikely to be responsible for this patient’s symptoms, given that he is receiving chronic valacyclovir to suppress HSV and that resistance to this drug is relatively uncommon except in severely immunosuppressed hosts.

E) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus proctocolitis would be rare in a person with HIV who has a CD4 count >100 cells per mm3.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 21-year-old man reports 8 days of penile discharge. He states that he does not have fever, chills, rash, or other systemic symptoms. He takes no medications. He is sexually active with several female partners and reports inconsistent condom use.
His vital signs are normal. He has normal male external genitalia without inguinal lymphadenopathy or lesions; purulent material is expressed from the urethral meatus.
Nucleic acid amplification testing is positive for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and negative for Chlamydia trachomatis infection.
Which one of the following therapies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Single dose of intramuscular benzathine penicillin G

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Penicillin is the drug of choice for syphilis infection, but it is not an effective treatment for N. gonorrhoeae.

B) CORRECT:

The most likely causes of uncomplicated, purulent urethritis in a sexually active young man are Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

Definitive diagnosis of N. gonorrhoeae infection can be made with nucleic-acid amplification testing of a urethral or urine sample; this test has largely replaced culture in clinical practice. Gram stain of the purulent exudate, when available, typically shows gram-negative diplococci.

If testing confirms isolated gonococcal urethritis, without concomitant C. trachomatis infection, then the recommended treatment is a single dose of ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscularly (or 1000 mg if the patient weighs ≥150 kg). There is currently no recommended oral regimen to treat gonococcal infection:

• Although prior guidelines recommended treating gonorrheal infection with a single dose of ceftriaxone 250 mg intramuscularly plus a single dose of oral azithromycin, N. gonorrhoeae has demonstrated increasing resistance to azithromycin. Thus, current guidelines recommend avoiding azithromycin use in patients with gonococcal disease.
• Oral cephalosporins, such as cefpodoxime, are also not recommended because of concerns for resistance.
• Oral doxycycline for 7 days is the preferred treatment for chlamydial urethritis, but it is not effective against gonococcal infection. An alternative treatment for chlamydial urethritis is a single dose of azithromycin but only if coinfection with N. gonorrhoeae has been ruled out.

Key learning point: The most appropriate therapy for gonococcal urethritis is a single dose of ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscularly.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral cephalosporins, such as cefpodoxime, are also not recommended because of concerns for resistance.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline for 7 days is the preferred treatment for chlamydial urethritis, but it is not effective against gonococcal infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Although prior guidelines recommended treating gonorrheal infection with a single dose of ceftriaxone 250 mg intramuscularly plus a single dose of oral azithromycin, N. gonorrhoeae has demonstrated increasing resistance to azithromycin. Thus, current guidelines recommend avoiding azithromycin use in patients with gonococcal disease. An alternative treatment for chlamydial urethritis is a single dose of azithromycin but only if coinfection with N. gonorrhoeae has been ruled out.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman reports a 2-week history of left-knee pain and swelling that started shortly after her last menstrual period ended. She also had fevers and migratory arthralgias during the initial 5 days, but those have since resolved. She has no past history of similar episodes.
She has a temperature of 37.6°C, a heart rate of 84 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 124/70 mm Hg. The left knee, which is painful on both active and passive range of motion, is slightly warm to the touch. An effusion is present, but there is no overlying erythema.
Analysis of synovial fluid from the knee reveals a leukocyte count of 50,000 per mm3 with 80% polymorphonuclear cells, no crystals visualized on light microscopy, and negative Gram stain and culture.
Which one of the following diagnostic approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Vaginal nucleic acid amplification assay for Neisseria gonorrhoeae
Antinuclear antibody testing and rheumatoid-factor testing

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with disseminated gonococcal infection initially develop fevers, chills, and malaise. As the fever resolves, patients typically present either with a triad of tenosynovitis, dermatitis, and polyarthralgias or with frank arthritis. Overlap in these presentations is frequent. The tenosynovitis generally affects multiple tendons at once; the dermatitis often manifests as relatively few, transient pustular or vesicular skin lesions. Without treatment, patients who initially present with the triad will usually progress to joint involvement. The arthritis usually affects only a single joint, and the most common joints affected are the knees, wrists, and ankles.

The diagnosis of disseminated gonococcal infection is typically made from a positive blood or synovial fluid culture for Neisseria gonorrhoeae, but those cultures are positive in only about 50% of cases. Vaginal (or other urogenital), rectal, and pharyngeal cultures or nucleic acid amplification assays are positive in 50% to 80% of patients with disseminated gonococcal infection, even when the patients are asymptomatic at these local sites.

Key learning point: Disseminated gonococcal infection presents as a transient systemic illness and can be followed by gonococcal arthritis, which is typically monoarticular.

B) INCORRECT:

CH50 blood testing screens for complement deficiencies. Although patients with C5–C9 deficiencies are at risk for recurrent Neisseria infections, obtaining this test is not useful in identifying the cause. Other risk factors for disseminated gonococcal infections include recent menstruation, pregnancy, and systemic lupus erythematosus.

C) INCORRECT:

Testing of factor VIII is useful if hemophilia A is suspected. However, the synovial fluid would be bloody.

D) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibody and rheumatoid-factor testing can be useful in evaluating arthritis related to connective-tissue disorders, which typically manifest as polyarticular rather than monoarticular arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus infection typically causes symmetric polyarticular arthritis, not monoarticular suppurative arthritis, and is diagnosed by parvovirus serologic testing of immunoglobulin M and G.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman with no prior medical problems reports a one-week history of pain and swelling in her left knee that has become progressively worse. She denies any trauma to the joint. She has also developed fevers, chills, and dysuria.
On examination, her temperature is 37.7°C, her heart rate is 90 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 110/78 mm Hg. Her left knee is warm, with decreased range of motion and a large effusion. A full neurologic and skin examination reveals no abnormalities.
Urinalysis reveals 2+ leukocyte esterase and no blood. Lyme antibody testing is negative. Blood and urine cultures have no growth.
A radiograph of the knee reveals an effusion without bony abnormalities. Arthrocentesis yields cloudy synovial fluid with a total leukocyte count of 52,500 cells per mm3 with 95% neutrophils. The synovial fluid contains no crystals and is sterile by evaluation with Gram stain and culture.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Nucleic acid amplification tests or culture for Neisseria gonorrhoeae of urogenital and extragenital sites

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A serum uric acid test is not appropriate, as gout is unlikely given the absence of crystals in the synovial fluid aspirate.

B) CORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes arthritis in two ways. In the first, disseminated gonococcal infection, the pathogen spreads through the bloodstream, causing pustular or vesiculopustular skin lesions, constitutional symptoms, and tenosynovitis or arthritis that is often sterile. In the second, the pathogen causes true joint infection that manifests as a monoarticular or oligoarticular purulent arthritis, often without other symptoms or findings, although symptoms of disseminated infection can precede or coexist with true joint infection; the knee is the joint most commonly affected. N. gonorrhoeae is difficult to culture; blood and synovial fluid cultures are negative in approximately 50% of patients.

If synovial fluid cultures are negative, nucleic acid amplification tests or culture for Neisseria gonorrhoeae of urogenital and extragenital sites should be performed. Because even this type of testing is imperfect, empiric treatment with antibiotics is often appropriate. Symptoms of gonococcal infection often improve rapidly with treatment. Chlamydia testing is done to distinguish reactive arthritis (which can be triggered by Chlamydia) from gonococcal infection.

Key learning point: The most appropriate diagnostic test for a woman with dysuria, pyuria, and an acute monoarthritis whose synovial fluid cultures are negative is nucleic acid amplification tests or culture for Neisseria gonorrhoeae of urogenital and extragenital sites.

C) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the knee is useful to evaluate the etiology of a noninflammatory joint effusion, but it is not useful in diagnosing early inflammatory arthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor and antinuclear antibody testing are not priorities in this setting. Rheumatoid arthritis and lupus are unusual causes of monoarthritis, although a patient with these disorders may have monoarthritis as the initial presentation. In addition, the acuity of the clinical presentation in this case is not classic for rheumatoid arthritis or lupus and would make these diagnoses less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor and antinuclear antibody testing are not priorities in this setting. Rheumatoid arthritis and lupus are unusual causes of monoarthritis, although a patient with these disorders may have monoarthritis as the initial presentation. In addition, the acuity of the clinical presentation in this case is not classic for rheumatoid arthritis or lupus and would make these diagnoses less likely.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old female college student reports a 2-week history of left-knee pain and swelling that started shortly after her last menstrual period ended. She also had fevers and migratory arthralgias during the initial 5 days, but those have since resolved. She has no past history of similar episodes.
She has a temperature of 37.6°C, a heart rate of 84 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 124/70 mm Hg. The left knee, which is painful on both active and passive range of motion, is slightly warm to the touch. An effusion is present, but there is no overlying erythema.
Analysis of synovial fluid from the knee reveals a leukocyte count of 50,000 per mm3 with 80% polymorphonuclear cells, no crystals visualized on light microscopy, and negative Gram stain and culture.
Which one of the following diagnostic approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Antinuclear antibody testing and rheumatoid-factor testing
Vaginal nucleic acid amplification assay for Neisseria gonorrhoeae

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibody and rheumatoid-factor testing can be useful in evaluating arthritis related to connective-tissue disorders, which typically manifest as polyarticular rather than monoarticular arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Testing of factor VIII would be useful if hemophilia A were suspected, but the synovial fluid would be bloody, and this condition is not typically seen in females because it is X-linked. Furthermore, it is rarely diagnosed outside of infancy or early childhood.

C) INCORRECT:

CH50 blood testing screens for complement deficiencies. Although patients with C5–C9 deficiencies are at risk for recurrent Neisseria infections, obtaining this test is not useful in identifying the cause. Other risk factors for disseminated gonococcal infections include recent menstruation, pregnancy, and systemic lupus erythematosus.

D) CORRECT:

Patients with disseminated gonococcal infection initially develop fevers, chills, and malaise. As the fever resolves, patients typically present either with a triad of tenosynovitis, dermatitis, and polyarthralgias or with frank arthritis. Overlap in these presentations is frequent. The tenosynovitis generally affects multiple tendons at once; the dermatitis often manifests as relatively few, transient pustular or vesicular skin lesions. Without treatment, patients who initially present with the triad will usually progress to joint involvement. The arthritis most commonly affects knees, wrists, and ankles in a monoarticular fashion, less commonly as an asymmetric polyarticular arthritis.

The diagnosis of disseminated gonococcal infection is typically made from a positive blood or synovial fluid culture for Neisseria gonorrhoeae, but those cultures are positive in only about 50% of cases. Vaginal (or other urogenital), rectal, and pharyngeal cultures or nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) are positive in 50% to 80% of patients with disseminated gonococcal infection, even when the patients are asymptomatic at these local sites. Testing these sites is critical to the diagnosis, particularly when the synovial fluid Gram stain is negative. Synovial fluid should also be examined for N. gonorrhoeae by NAAT.

Key learning point: Disseminated gonococcal infection presents as a transient systemic illness and can be followed by gonococcal arthritis, which is typically monoarticular.

E) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus infection typically causes symmetric polyarticular arthritis, not monoarticular suppurative arthritis, and affects the small joints of the hands, wrists, and ankles. It is diagnosed by parvovirus serologic testing.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the office because of a 2-day history of pain in her right knee. Last week she had right wrist pain. She has no history of recent trauma. She returned from summer camp in Connecticut 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Examination shows several painless vesiculopustular lesions on the back and one lesion on the right sole of the foot. There is swelling of the right knee with tenderness to palpation. Passive extension of the right wrist and fingers elicits pain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis typically presents with a triad of urethritis, conjunctivitis, and migratory arthritis most commonly in young adults. While this patient presents with migratory arthritis, other associated symptoms of reactive arthritis are absent. She also has no history of recent gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections, making this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common overall cause of septic arthritis in adults, children > 2 years of age, and in patients, who have recently undergone invasive joint procedures. Staphylococcal septic arthritis typically presents with fever, joint pain, and swelling of the affected joint, most commonly the knee, as seen in this patient. However, in young adults who are sexually active, such as this patient, Staphylococcus aureus is not the most likely cause of septic arthritis, nor does it manifest with migratory arthritis, tenosynovitis, or a painless vesiculopustular rash.

C) INCORRECT:

Lyme arthritis is a clinical feature of late Lyme disease (stage III) and can manifest with intermittent arthritis. While this patient's recent summer camp in Connecticut puts her at an increased risk of contracting tick-borne diseases, late Lyme disease develops months to years after a tick bite. Moreover, a vesiculopustular rash is not typically seen in Lyme disease.
Image Description:

Left torso of a patient

A round, erythematous skin lesion with discrete central scaling and typical target-shape appearance is seen.

These findings are highly suggestive of erythema chronicum migrans in Lyme disease.

D) CORRECT:

Infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the second most commonly reported infectious disease in the US and can manifest in a localized (e.g., urethritis, pelvic inflammatory disease) or disseminated (arthritis-dermatitis syndrome, purulent gonococcal arthritis) form. The disease is most commonly transmitted during unprotected sexual intercourse. Arthritis-dermatitis syndrome typically manifests with migratory, asymmetric arthritis, tenosynovitis, and vesicular, pustular, or maculopapular lesions on the trunk and extremities (sometimes involving the palms and soles), as seen in this patient.

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a common cause of septic arthritis in sexually active young adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with acute rheumatic fever usually present with migratory arthritis and cutaneous lesions, as does this patient. In contrast to the painless vesiculopustular lesions described here, though, cutaneous manifestations include subcutaneous nodules and erythema marginatum (annular erythema on the trunk and extremities). Additionally, the condition is usually associated with other symptoms such as pancarditis or Sydenham chorea and is preceded by a history of streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis.
questions.hint: There are many conditions that can cause both dermatitis and oligoarthritis, but the accompanying fever, painless vesiculopustular lesions, tenosynovitis (pain on passive extension of wrist and fingers), and lack of prior illness or other symptoms may help distinguish between them.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of fever and severe left knee pain for the past week. She has not sustained any trauma or injury to the area, nor has she traveled or taken part in outdoor activities in the recent past. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. She appears ill. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F). Physical examination shows multiple painless pustular lesions on her ankles and the dorsum and soles of her feet bilaterally, as well as a swollen, erythematous, exquisitely tender left knee. Her wrists are also mildly edematous and tender, with pain on extension. An x-ray of the knees shows tissue swelling. Arthrocentesis of the knee shows yellow purulent fluid. Gram stain is pending. Analysis of the synovial fluid shows a leukocyte count of 58,000/mm3 with 93% neutrophils. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Empiric therapy with IV vancomycin and ceftazidime is the treatment of choice in patients with septic arthritis if Gram stain is negative and there are no risk factors for STDs. Vancomycin is effective against gram-positive bacteria such as Staphylococcus aureus (including MRSA), and ceftazidime is effective against gram-negative rods such as Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas. This patient's presentation is consistent with DGI, which requires different management.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral penicillin V is used to treat streptoccocal infections or for prophylaxis in diseases like rheumatic fever (RF). Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory condition that affects the heart, joints, skin, and brain and commonly develops after a streptococcal throat infection. Even though this woman fulfills one of the major criteria for RF (polyarthritis), she has no history of preceding streptoccocal infection, nor are the other criteria fulfilled (e.g., signs of carditis, erythema marginatum, Sydenham chorea, or subcutaneous nodules), making RF unlikely. RF would also not explain this patient's pustular dermatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydroxychloroquine is an antimalarial drug that is also used in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) because of its anti-inflammatory effect. However, this patient lacks typical features of SLE (e.g., malar rash, weight loss, pain in the small joints) or RA (joint pain and stiffness in the hands and fingers). More importantly, the arthrocentesis results here indicate septic arthritis, whereas both RA and SLE would involve aseptic joint inflammation (leukocyte count typically < 50,000 mm3).

D) CORRECT:

Intravenous or intramuscular ceftriaxone is the preferred initial treatment for DGI. Although this patient only has signs of gonococcal infection, coinfection with chlamydia is common (and has not been excluded here), and oral doxycycline is used to treat it. In addition to treating the patient, testing and treatment should be offered to her sexual contacts. Although Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a bacteria that can be seen on Gram stain and routine culture of synovial fluid, these tests are positive in less than 50% of samples and are therefore unreliable. Instead, nucleic acid amplification is conducted to confirm the diagnosis.
Image Description:

Infectious pustule with accompanying erythema on the palmar side of index finger.

E) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is an antibiotic that may be used to treat Lyme disease. The disseminated form of Lyme disease can also manifest with polyarthritis. However, this patient has no history of exposure to the outdoors and patients with Lyme disease normally have erythema migrans during the first stage (before signs of dissemination), not a pustular rash. Furthermore, joint fluid analysis in Lyme disease would show aseptic inflammation (leukocyte count typically < 50,000 mm3).
questions.hint: Pustular dermatitis that involves the soles of the feet, septic arthritis, and a history of inconsistent condom use suggest disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI).
